pullRequest.body:
This PR introduces the functor `map : Comma L R ‚•§ Comma L' R'` induced by three functors `F‚ÇÅ`, `F‚ÇÇ`, `F` and two natural transformations `F‚ÇÅ ‚ãô L' ‚ü∂ L ‚ãô F` and `R ‚ãô F ‚ü∂ F‚ÇÇ ‚ãô R'`. Variants for `StructuredArrow` and `CostructuredArrow` are also introduced.

All the basic functors between `Comma` categories are special cases of this one, but their definition was not changed: it would break too many defeq.

---

This shall be used in the study of Kan extensions of functors and derived functors.

<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

nodes.body:
Thanks!
maintainer merge
üöÄ Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by erdOne.
In general, if the instance graph is touched, benchmarking should be done also.
!benchmark

Here are the [benchmark results](http://speed.lean-fro.org/mathlib4/run-detail/adbcf258-f6bb-45cc-92ff-4194791ecbaa) for commit c9ff66bab5bb1840b3522f75ce1595d59e7b9cbf.
There were [significant changes](http://speed.lean-fro.org/mathlib4/compare/c7db97b8-def1-40e4-869c-bca35e1c9430/to/adbcf258-f6bb-45cc-92ff-4194791ecbaa) against commit 50ad8e5b632350c48a75130cedfb23d9863a5f5b:
```diff
  Benchmark                             Metric         Change
  ===========================================================
+ ~Mathlib.CategoryTheory.Comma.Basic   instructions   -21.8%
```

As `Functor.Full` is now a Prop since #12449, and `Functor.IsEquivalence` should be so in a near future (see refactor PR #12462), it seems to me there should no longer be any objection about potential issues related to reducibility and unification?

Thanks for your patience with me and for all you do!

bors delegate+

:v: joelriou can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).
bors merge

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/9002010943/job/24729409114)
  * [Check all files imported](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/9002010943/job/24729409713)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/9002010943/job/24729410274)
I wonder if these should be redefined with the new definition? Or maybe even as abbrevs so that the new instances can apply as well?
I have already tried, but it breaks too many things.
I saw that in the PR message just now. Oops.

This is used in constructing instances below so needs to be `reducible`. 

I suspect there are existing violations which are out of scope for this PR.
I am sorry I do not understand what you mean.
See the other chain of comments for more explanation.

Here we use `preLeftIso`. If typeclass search calls unification, then it only allows unfolding of declarations that are `reducible` or projections on instances classes. Thus `preLeftIso` will not unfold and unification might fail because of this. 

This is a general policy (see the corresponding library note). While things build right now, we need to make sure theoretically defeq instances are functionally defeq to avoid future problems.
Does this explanation help?

`Functor.Faithful` is a Prop, so that I cannot see how this could be a problem. For `Functor.Full`, it may, but then I do not see how making `preLeftIso` reducible would improve things: the definitions `Full.ofIso`, `NatIso.ofComponents` and `Iso.refl` are not reducible either... (I think that `Full` and `IsEquivalence` should be made Props, because we should not rely on the definitional properties of the witness given by a `Full` instance.)

Yes. This is bad example. I just took the first one. Apologies. 

All of `Full.ofIso` etc. should be made reducible (though not in this PR). Or there should be some refactor to carry no data. 

As I mentioned, I realize there is already a problem with the library as it currently exists. I just don't want to add to that problem here and make more to fix later.
I think the better plan is to make `Full` and `IsEquivalence` a `Prop` in a near future. Then, the content of this PR would not require any modification.

I think that is good idea yet. But I don't understand the force of the objection to marking things `reducible` for now, tagging with an issue to remove data from `Full` and `IsEquivalence`, and then cleaning things up later. 

Could you explain a bit more? Thanks
I guess it is just more work to do when doing the refactor, without much gain (since `Functor.Full.of_iso` is not marked `reducible`) ?
Is `Full.ofIso` used before this in instance constructions? Either way, it should be made `reducible` also since it used here.
We really need to get the notes back into the API documentation: https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib_docs/notes.html#reducible%20non-instances

There are other instances which uses `Full.ofIso`... I understand that there might be a problem here.

However, the right solution (*which I intend to implement*) is obviously to remove data from `Full` and `IsEquivalence` (and there are even more problematic instances: basically all the `PreservesLimit` stuff... nothing is reducible there). For instances where the carried data is of an extreme importance (algebraic operations on types, preorders, etc), I understand the need to mark things as reducible, but this is not at all the case here! Even if we were to mark everything as reducible, definitions of instances may be more automatically unfolded, but it is mostly unlikely that we get defeq of two concurrent instances (because in category theory definitions, we have extra compositions with identities everywhere and compositions may be "associated" in differents ways). As Andrew points out, if I were to mark a few definitions as reducible now, it would be more work afterwards when the `Prop`-refactor is done...

The `reducible` attribute is almost never used in the category theory API. Maybe we should use it more: one annoying thing is that when we define the `Hom` type of a category and setup an `ext` lemma for this `Hom` type, then we have to systematically restate the ext lemma for the type synonym of morphisms `X ‚ü∂ Y` once the `Category` instance has been defined... I am not qualified to know how this could be fixed by marking certains things reducible, but this is a real issue...

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat(CategoryTheory): more functoriality for Comma categories
